column4: noisemo, I think I may not have explained what I'm after very well.  I want a command that gives me a list of just the folders within a directory.
man ls ^^
I can't seem to find anything within man ls.  It doesn't seem to have the capability to list only the directories.
hmm.. was sure there was something, you can use "ls -l | grep ^d" though I guess
although that might be a bit too verbose
depending on what you're doing
the ^d means "starting with d"?
yup
that might work.  Odd that ls doesn't have the capability.  It seems to be able to do everything else.
yeah, I was surprised too
ls -F is pretty good to have as default too, makes it easier to see what's directories (maybe that's enabled by default in ubuntu though)
I use the colors (ls --color) to distinguish files from folders.
they work good i pairs =)
especially if you have lousy memory like me and forget what the different colors mean =)
I just came across a solution elsewhere:  ls -d */
still not all clean, but better =)
I still can't fathom ls not being able to do it properly, though.  After all MS-DOS can do it.
me neither, but I won't go through the roof until I talk with some real guru, for all I know there's an obscure command that does only this
True.  This has bugged me for a while, though.  Many a time it would have been handy.  There are lots of kludge workarounds but nothing satisfying.
yeah, I thought about it a long time ago, but haven't really needed it since, I don't do any shell scriptingt, so ls -l | grep ^d has worked for me when I really needed it
ls -d */ will not list hidden directories, such as .mozilla in your home directory :-(
that's weird, -a don't seem to work together with -d
yeah, really =(
